turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Levander, you may continue.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

The Court of Appeals concluded and the respondent agrees that the due process clause requires either that the district judge defer to the magistrate's proposed findings of fact or to rehear the testimony, but this analysis doesn't make any sense in the facts of this case.
Here the District Court adopted the magistrate's findings.
If the District Court had merely deferred to the magistrate's findings, it would have again denied the motion.
That it made a more thorough review and did not defer could not possibly have deprived the respondent of any kind of procedural protections.
In fact, he received more protection because he got a more thorough review.

We also believe that the Court of Appeals analysis is flawed in failing to consider the three facts that this Court has set forth which should be considered in determining what process is due in a particular circumstance.
That is the personal interest involved, the risk of erroneous deprivation of that interest, and the government's administrative and financial interests in adhering to the procedure set forth.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Counsel, supposing the magistrate had decided the other way and on review, that is had held that the statement should be suppressed, and on review at the instance of the government, without taking any additional evidence, the court had overruled that determination, would you say it still would be just a -- there would be no purpose to having -- then would you say the standard didn't make any difference?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: No, the standard would certainly be different because he would be able to review and overturn him, that is the District Court would be able to overturn the magistrate even though the findings of fact were not "clearly erroneous."
He would be able to overturn --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: He could do it without taking any additional evidence?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That's right.
Now --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But you said the defendant really doesn't get hurt by the Court of Appeals position but he might be hurt if it had gone the other way for the magistrate, is what I am saying.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: But I think in this criminal case the respondent can't raise the deprivation that might occur to others.
Here in this case, he had a full and fair hearing before the magistrate.
The magistrate made proposed findings of fact against him.

Those findings have ample support in the record and the District Court, upon making a thorough review of that record, the magistrate's report and the submissions of the parties concluded that the motion should be denied.
The case would be a more difficult one perhaps where it was purely a swearing contest between a defendant and a --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But your view of the procedure -- now you are saying he doesn't have standing to make this argument, and I have to think that through -- but your view of the procedure is that even if it is a swearing contest between the officer and the defendant, the district judge may nevertheless in its so-called de novo review reverse the finding of the magistrate without hearing any additional evidence.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That is a much more difficult question.
When it is purely a swearing contest -- and the evidence is equally balanced --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, as a matter of statutory construction, you say that that is what Congress intended.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Haven't we hinted if we have not held that credibility findings are rarely if ever to be reviewed on a cold record?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: You have to --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Or to reverse them, on the hypothetical that Justice Stevens has just posed.
Is it not one thing to affirm credibility findings on a cold record and quite another to reverse them on a cold record?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Yes, it is, Mr. Chief Justice, and that is why we say in our brief that the District Court could reverse the magistrate's proposed findings in a case like this one, for example, where there are objective factors in the record to support the magistrate, what the magistrate actually concluded.

But let's assume that the magistrate concluded that he believed respondent, well, there are various objective factors in this record which make respondent's testimony fairly incredible at points, from which upon reading from the cold record you can tell that the respondent -- he admitted that he lied on November 19th, his August 8th -- he claims he made no statement on August 8th, yet that statement that is attributed to him by the Chicago police and appears in the arrest report is the same statement that he admits having made on January 12th.
And it is just inherently incredible that the Chicago police made up a statement which respondent admits that he subsequently made in January following his arrest.
So in this kind of a case, where there are objective factors aside from the just a pure swearing contest, the District Court in making its de novo determination could reverse the magistrate.
Obviously, the District Court is on shaky ground in those circumstances where it is purely a swearing contest and he simply reverses the magistrate, and that is a much more --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He believes that the trier of facts disbelieve, is that the kind of a case you are posing?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Well, that would be difficult to do, but here we don't have that problem, of course, because he adopted the magistrate's findings.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Was it not difficult under the statute?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The statute makes no distinction.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That's correct, but due process may come into play at some point where it is purely a swearing contest and the District Court reverses the magistrate.
Of course, as I said before, that did not happen here.
The magistrate evaluated the respondent's testimony and he found it not to be credible and the District Court adopted those findings.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Let me test that out with this hypothetical.
Suppose the magistrate made careful and detailed findings that he believed the defendant and disbelieved the officers and therefore recommended the suppression of the testimony.
Now, the District Judge reading the record and nothing more reverses the district judge on the credibility finding, do you mean that would give rise to due process questions?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Yes, although that would be similar to what happens in agency proceedings.

The same kind of relationship that exists between the magistrate and the District Court exists in agency proceedings, in the British special master situation, in special masters in original cases in this Court, and normally the reviewing court or the court that has the power to enter the judgment does not simply toss aside the magistrate's findings, and it normally would give them credit for what are worth based on his independent review of the record.

And when the reviewing court reviews, let's say, the SEC's determination of something, it may be that the ALJ concluded adversely to the agency's finding of fact, and that is something again under Universal Camera Corp., this Court's decision in Universal Camera Corp., that the reviewing court can take into account as to whether there is substantial evidence in the record or whether the District Court's determination is erroneous.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But don't you take into account the difference between findings of fact generally and findings of fact based entirely on credibility of the speaker?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That is absolutely correct.

And where, of course, the only issue is credibility, the District Court, if you wanted to reverse the magistrate and the only issue was credibility and the evidence was equipoised between the defendant and the police officer, then the District Court cannot simply ignore the magistrate's determination of credibility.
If you wish to reverse the magistrate in that circumstance, he would probably have to rehear the testimony or recommit it back to the magistrate for further findings.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You say he would probably have to do that.
What would require him to do it?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Due process.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you think the Constitution would require him to do that?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Because in the case in which there was solely credibility at issue --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Isn't that about what Judge Sprecher said this case was, that you have a credibility determination and therefore due process requires the judge hear the evidence himself?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It just that they are affirming instead of reversing.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: But that is a big difference because here an impartial neutral Article 3 adjunct has evaluated the credibility and made specific findings about that credibility and the District Court has credited those findings based on his independent review of the record, so therefore, just like an --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What if he says on the review, well, I really can't tell because you've got a swearing contest here, but even though the statute directs me to give a de novo hearing, there is really no way to do it but I will just assume they are probably right.
Could he have done that?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Yes, and then he would be giving the magistrate's report that credibility which it is due.

He would say I trust the magistrate, the magistrate has made a finding, having viewed credibility, the magistrate is equally competent as the district judge to evaluate a simple matter of credibility.
Juries are entrusted in our system to evaluate credibility, and it doesn't take a --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What do the words de novo determination mean then?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: A much more thorough review than a simple clearly erroneous standard.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, de novo doesn't -- doesn't de novo ordinarily mean you are privileged to submit additional evidence to the reviewer?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: When it says de novo hearing or de novo review.
This is a de novo determination of the magistrate's report.
That is what the statute says, and the legislative history makes quite clear that Congress did not intend the District Courts to rehear testimony on contested issues.
That statement appears over and over again in the legislative history.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Then why do they use the words de novo?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: To contrast it to subsection (a) in which the magistrate hears and determines motions and the District Court must give deference on a clearly erroneous standard to the magistrate's findings.
The Court of Appeals in our view simply misevaluated the three factors underlying the due process analysis.

In Lego v. Twomey, this Court made clear that a suppression hearing does not implicate the important issue of guilt or innocence, it is simply a matter of the conduct of the police that is in question and the question is whether or not evidence which is wholly probative and relevant shall be kept out because of the conduct of the police.

Second, the Court of Appeals viewed this to be a very -- have a high risk of erroneous deprivation, yet this same kind of proceeding has been used in England for many years, it is used in all of the administrative agencies, and it is used by this Court in its original jurisdiction cases.
And finally, the Court of Appeals did not at all address the government's substantial interests in using magistrates.

There is a terrible problem of congested litigation and magistrates in a recent article appearing in 16 Harvard Journal of Legislation, it has been shown that a study shows that the use of magistrates has increased by a third the ability of District Courts to dispose of cases.
In 1979, over 3,000 evidentiary hearings were conducted by magistrates under section 636(b)(1)(B), a considerable saving of time.
And these things were not addressed by the Court of Appeals at all.
I would like to reserve the rest of my time, if I might.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Ms. Gottschall.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

As the government stated this morning, the Magistrates Act not only withholds from the magistrate decision-making power with respect to case dispositive motions, but it expressly provides that if any party objects to any finding or any recommendation of the magistrate "a judge of the court shall make a de novo determination of those portions of the report or specified proposed findings to which objection is made."

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Laying aside for a moment what differences if any there may be between de novo determination and a de novo hearing, would you -- do you think there is a difference between a district judge affirming a magistrate's finding on credibility and reversing a finding on credibility?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I do not.
I think that the question is whether the district judge is in a position to make an independent determination.

If all the district judge does is looks at what the magistrate has done and says, well, this is a credibility finding, I obviously don't have the evidence before me to reevaluate that, I don't see how that can possibly be explained as any kind of a de novo determination of anything, and I think that is the difference between what the Court of Appeals felt and the position that the government is urging now.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What do you think is the difference between a de novo determination and a de novo hearing?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I don't believe there is any difference, and I think that the prior decisions of this Court established that very clearly.
First of all, let me just point out that this act does not use the word hearing the way the government suggests, that is an evidentiary hearing.
This act speaks of hearing motions for summary judgment and motions to dismiss complaints and all kinds of things that are not evidentiary.

And this Court, in the case of United States v. First City National Bank, had virtually an identical argument before it, where a party claimed that because a statute spoke of de novo review rather than trial de novo that there was to be more limited judicial review, and the Court rejected that.
It said that the critical concept is de novo and what de novo means is that there has to be an independent determination of the issue.
And I would just suggest that in many decisions of this Court, virtually all the decisions of this Court talk about de novo, all of these terms are used interchangeably.
I think this is quite clearly a distinction without a difference.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you have to have a whole new hearing?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I don't believe so, Mr. Justice Marshall.

I think that what it appears that the act contemplated was that the district judge would be able to evaluate on what issues it would be necessary for him to rehear evidence in order to make a de novo determination.
Now, the case is established that one of those issues is credibility.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Well, wouldn't it end up in a new hearing?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: As to credibility questions, yes.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Well, what good is sending out the magistrate if he is going to have two hearings?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Well, there are a lot of ways the statute --

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Do you think Congress meant to establish another hearing, an extra hearing?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: What I believe the Congress was trying to do was to take some of these motions away from district judges to the extent possible, while preserving the district judge's ability to make a decision of those issues.

And I think that the suggestion that the statute is rendered useless because in cases where credibility was critical or some other source of evidence that wasn't included in the record required rehearing, I don't think that is true.

I would expect that there area great many matters where if there is an initial hearing before a judicial magistrate, there can be a stipulated record developed, a question of law can surface, and many different things can happen that will avoid the necessity of having to rehear the evidence.
I would suggest that a real swearing contest such as occurred in this case is really rather unusual.

Perhaps not in confession cases -- the Court has noted the confession cases typically involve this kind of thing, but in all the great variety of matters that are covered by section 636(b)(1)(B), I would expect that credibility would not be the critical issue in that many cases.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In suppression of tangible evidence cases, do you say it would not be?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I don't think it would be uniformly.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Not uniformly but overwhelmingly.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: That would --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: There are contests of credibility.
I say that on the basis of having reviewed almost literally thousands of records in the courts of appeals, when the court of appeals had general jurisdiction over the District of Columbia.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Well, I think it may be a different question --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I'm not sure it makes a difference, but I think your statement of the fact is not based on -- not consistent with my observations.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: There is a different kind of credibility question I would think in Fourth Amendment cases, in the generality of cases.
In general, there would be one probably police officers testifying as to perhaps articulable facts that they observed that they contend amounted to probable cause --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The evidence was in plain sight and the defendant says no, it was not in plain sight, it was in his back pocket, and that sort of thing.
Isn't that typical of the type of evidence you have?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Well, I don't know exactly how many or what percentage of Fourth Amendment suppression motions would raise this kind of credibility question.
It may be that suppression motions do raise credibility questions in the majority of cases.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You might well argue that if in fact they are overwhelmingly credibility contests, that is the reason for an Article 3 judge to hear them.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I would think that is right because in that situation the independence of a decision-maker is critically important.

I would point out that I think the legislative history is very clear that credibility findings and findings of fact in which credibility figured were very clearly covered by the de novo review provision.

There is really no question on the basis of this legislative history that Congress contemplated that credibility issues would be redetermined just like any other issues, that any finding of fact of the magistrate would be subject to this de novo review provision.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, I would have reached almost the opposite conclusion from hearing the government's argument that the statutory language probably is in your favor, but that the legislative history is against you.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I think there are two questions, Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

The first question is the standard of review when a finding is objected to, and I don't believe that there is any conflict between the parties in this case that the judge is supposed to make an independent determination of the issue.
The government states in its brief that the judge would be violating the statue if he deferred to the magistrate on fact-findings.
So I think on that point there is agreement.
The problem arises on the question of what procedures the judge has to follow in evaluating the magistrate's recommendations.

And what the legislative history says, it is true that the statement that the government has quoted consistently in its brief, the use of the words de novo determination is not intended to require the judge to actually conduct a new hearing on contested issues, that is true.

But the government consistently omits the two explanatory sentences which follow, which state that normally the judge upon application would consider the record which has been developed before the magistrate and make his own determination on the basis of that record.

But in some specific instances, however, it may be necessary for the judge to modify or reject the findings of the magistrate, take additional evidence, to recall witnesses or to recommit the matter to the magistrate for further proceedings.
There is no question that Congress contemplated that rehearing would be necessary in some cases.
And from the cases that Congress cited --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The government doesn't contend otherwise, does it?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Well, the government seems to --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I asked specifically if that was one of the options that was open to the judge, and the government said yes, that occasionally he would have a hearing himself.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: The government suggests though a completely unreviewable standard of discretion, that whether the judge decides to hear evidence or decides not to hear evidence is completely unreviewable.
It depends on how the judge feels that particular day.
That can't possibly be the law.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He also conceded that if a judge, a district judge reversed a credibility finding, it might -- I don't think he conceded it would, but it might well give rise to serious due process questions.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I think the question is whether the judge has to put himself in a position where he can fulfill the statutory requirement that he make a de novo determination.
The government's argument is basically saying that all the process that an objecting party is entitled to is to have the magistrate affirm.
If you objected to the magistrate's findings and if the judge affirmed the magistrate, there would be no problem.
But if you objected to the magistrate's findings and the district judge reversed the magistrate, well then there would be due process constraints on that

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What is your position with respect to say the magistrate granting a motion for summary judgment?

You don't have those in criminal cases, but suppose in a civil case, and it comes before the District Court, do you say that the judge -- there are affidavits on both sides so you call it a swearing contest, do you say the district judge must as a matter of law under this act hear the witnesses or at least read the affidavits himself?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Absolutely not.

I think that that case is covered by this Court's decision in Matthews v. Weber, where the parties can focus the judge's attention on the problems that they have with the magistrate's recommendation and the judge can go to the record and he has the evidence before him, it was before the magistrate, and with the guidance of the parties he can make an independent determination of whether or not the magistrate was correct.
I don't think there is any problem.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Suppose the District Court has denied a motion for summary judgment, saying there is a credibility issue here, I can't tell which of the parties is telling the truth, do you think the District Court could reverse that and say I have determined that one of the parties is telling the truth and the other isn't?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: On a motion for summary judgment?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: On affidavits?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: No, I don't think the law would permit that at all, I think that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That isn't permitted the magistrate or anybody.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: That's correct.

No, that is contrary to the whole notion of motions for summary judgment which our response is to the same concerns that the Court of Appeals was worried about here, making credibility determinations on the basis of cold records.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, the government doesn't argue that whatever judgment the district judge makes of the magistrate's findings isn't subject to review, does it?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: The government seems -- it appears to me that what the government is suggesting is something like a substantial evidence standard, which this Court has always said is equivalent to record review.

If regardless of the nature of the issues, all the judge does is look at the record, and really what the judge is doing is simply making sure that there is evidence in the record to support the magistrate's conclusion.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, what if the judge says I've read the record, I've read the written record, the record of the evidence, and I make my own determination as follows, and it just so happens that every determination agrees with the magistrate.
That wouldn't satisfy you.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: It would depend on whether the district judge --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know, but let's assume there that there are square conflicts in the evidence or in the testimony before the master.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That process wouldn't satisfy you.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You would think that the judge must call witnesses.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: If there is a testimonial conflict and credibility is -- if there were some --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I thought the government was saying that -- the government doesn't urge that the court is free not to make its own determination, does it?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: The government's position seems to be that the court has to make its own determination, although --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, it reads the record and makes its determinations and if there is a conflict it resolves them itself, and if it disagrees with the magistrate it disagrees, and if it agrees it agrees with the magistrate.
And if it wanted to it could have a hearing.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I think that whether what the judge does, whether it is permissible under established principles of due process and fair procedure depends on whether the judge has an adequate basis beforehand for making the decision, and that depends on the importance of issues such as credibility and basically on the state of the record and what kinds of issues it is that he is evaluating.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then he can send it to a magistrate.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: If the judge believes that it will assist him in the disposition of the cases, can send anything under section 636 to a magistrate.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But if there is any conflict he has to try it all over again?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: With respect to any findings to which objections are made and to the extend credibility or some issue --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So the only thing to prevent a defendant from getting two hearings is not to object?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: On a matter of credibility, I would agree with that, but I would point out that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you have many hearings that credibility isn't involved?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I frankly don't know how this comes out in the generality of cases.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I think it would help you if you don't need a hearing.
If there is not going to be disagreement, you don't need a hearing.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Mr. Justice Marshall, I don't think that is correct, for this reason.

In a criminal case, largely because of the discovery rules and a lot of other factors, the fact is that the parties do not know what the testimony is going to be at the suppression hearing before they hear it.
And in many suppression hearings that I have been involved in --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, you did object.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why did you object?
You didn't know but you objected?
You must have know something because you objected.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: To the admission of the evidence.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, you objected to it being referred to the magistrate.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Well, I expected that credibility would be an issue in this case and I told that to the district judge.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then you knew about credibility, so why wouldn't it be better to just have the magistrate?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: In this case I think it clearly would have been better.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So that is really what you are against, the magistrate, aren't you?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But Congress has overruled you, isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I don't think that is right.
I think that Congress has made a policy decision in the area of case dispositive motions that --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, who else can make that decision other than Congress?
Who else can make the decision as to the judicial process in this country other than Congress?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Well, I think the Constitution may put some restraints on that.

When you are talking about case dispositive motions and an Article 3 court and an issue arising directly the Fifth Amendment of the Constitution, I don't think the issue has to be reached in this case because of the de novo determination requirement, but the fact of the matter is that there may be constraints on the power of Congress.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If Congress had expressly said that magistrates will make findings of fact and resolve issues turning on credibility and that the district judge shall accept them if they are supported by substantial evidence, would you say that there is a constitutional issue?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I would.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I guess you would.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But nobody is being sent to jail as a result of the magistrate's denial of the suppression here, this suppression motion.
It required the stipulation of the parties to forego a trial in order to have the magistrate's hearing become what was in effect the trial record, did it not?
Had you been dissatisfied with the magistrate's ruling on the suppression motion and the District Court's affirmance of it, you could have gone ahead and had a full-scale trial.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I'm not entirely certain that the issues, all of the issues in this case at the suppression motion could have been tried before the jury, and certainly the decision of the jury would not be the decision that the law on the Firth Amendment itself in fact requires the judge to make in this case.
It would have been a different decision with different factors being important.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, what would have happened if you had not stipulated and the time came during the trial that the confession is offered in evidence? You certainly would have objected, would you not?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Well, under the rules my understanding is that once the pretrial motion has been decided adversely, there is no need to make an objection and that is the end of it, it is the law of the case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You can't object --

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: One might be able to.
You might be permitted to do it, but you certainly don't have to do it.
And if you were permitted to do it, you would be doing something somewhat different from what you are doing in a pretrial hearing.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But the issue of -- was it a voluntariness question, is that it?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Yes, it was, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you certainly are entitled to have that submitted to the jury.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: On the issue of reliability.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, how about voluntariness?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I've seen cases going both ways on that question in terms of the legal standard.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Have you seen one where it is denied if you ask or request to put on evidence about the voluntariness issue before the jury and have the judge instruct on it in the federal system?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I'm not sure, I can't really think of any case.

It wasn't my understanding that I would be allowed to relitigate the constitutional question apart from questions of reliability, the precise issue that the law required me to make as a pretrial again.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What authority do you have on that?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I may not be correct on that.
That has been my understanding.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I thought Jackson v. Denno said the judge had to make an initial determination and that many jurisdictions, including the federal, permitted the question of voluntariness to be submitted to the jury also.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Well, as I say, I'm not sure what the law is.
At least in some form I suspect I could have submitted that question to the jury, but that certainly would not serve the interests of the government that it is putting forth in its case.
If in order to have an Article 3 judge hear the evidence relevant to the Fifth Amendment issue I have to take a jury trial, it seems to me that that is probably as counter-productive of --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, that isn't congressional, that is Jackson v. Denno.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: At any rate, it may not serve the interests of the government, it would uphold the constitutionality of the statute.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I don't think that submitting the issue of voluntariness to the trial jury would be a satisfactory determination of the question of voluntariness under this Court's decisions.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Jackson v. Denno says maybe you have to submit it to the trial judge, too.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: My understanding of Jackson v. Denno is that it entitles the defendant to a hearing outside the presence of the trial jury on the issue of voluntariness, so I don't think that submitting that issue to the trial jury would be of consequence in terms of whether this is an adequate determination of the voluntariness question itself.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The judge may then submit it, allow it to go to the jury if he makes the appropriate findings under Jackson v. Denno, may he not?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, he may.
Once he has decided that it is admissible, then he is permitted to let it go to the jury.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In some jurisdictions, and I think the federal, if the defendant wants he can have the issue of voluntariness resubmitted to the jury.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Yes, I believe that is right.

I am still not entirely convinced that all of the evidence that might be relevant to the voluntariness employed on the pretrial hearing would be properly submitted to the jury, but certainly in some jurisdictions I understand that to be true.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Counsel, you have been asked questions about civil cases, and it is not clear to me whether you draw a distinction at all between civil and criminal cases.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I think that whether there is a distinction between civil and motions related to criminal cases, like suppression motions, would depend on whether one were to analyze this problem as a matter of a construction of the statute and the de novo determinations problem.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Let's think in terms of due process.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Perhaps not under the Seventh Circuit's opinion --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: -- but it seems to me that the importance of demeanor evidence in making credibility determinations is so much a part of all judicial process, whether it be criminal or civil, that while the interests at stake might not be as critical in say the preliminary injunction context, that that principle about demeanor evidence would probably make this holding in the extent of that context.
It would be a slightly different analysis.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You rely on Chief Justice Hugh's language in the first Oregon case which of course wasn't a simple case.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I'm not entirely sure.
I don't remember, it must have been but I --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, don't count on me for being infallible.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Counsel, is your submission as to criminal cases limited to situations where there is what we have been calling a swearing contest?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I think that that is the clearest case.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I think that in, for instance, the Fourth Amendment context which Mr. Chief Justice Burger mentioned, the analysis might be different.

For instance, in the summary judgment context, in considering for instance summary judgment in a case that was going to be tried to the bench rather than to a jury, so they weren't jury trial issues, the judge would have somewhat more latitude in resolving factual questions on the basis of affidavits than he would in some other context.

So whether, for instance, if at the hearing before the magistrate there was no conflicting testimony but there was a question of credibility, perhaps then a determination of which party had the burden might be relevant.
I think that that gets into a much more complicated situation.

But certainly where there is a swearing contest, the trial judge had no reasonable basis for making a de novo decision of the factual matters, and that was the basis for the Seventh Circuit's opinion.
The Seventh Circuit read the record and their conclusion was that it was simply impossible to determine the truth from that written record.
The evidence was simply too conflicting and too inconsistent.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How are magistrates appointed? What is their tenure and how long is their term?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Mr. Justice Stewart, they are appointed by the judges of the District Court, by a majority of the judges of the District Court.
The offices I believe are established by the Judicial Conference and their terms are eight-year terms.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Are they removable at will during the eight years?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: They are removable for a range of reasons, including incompetence, neglect of duty --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: For cause.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Yes, that's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Not at will.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: That's correct, there has to be some kind of a hearing I think before they are removed.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Eight-year terms?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What would you say to a state proceeding which originally went before a JP, tried by him and the state statute provided for a de novo review by the superior court of the circuit or whatever the court of general jurisdiction was?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: My understanding of those statutes is that the defendant is entitled to have the trial again in the higher level court, that it isn't a record review but it is a relitigation of the issues.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You say here you fell that you are not entitled to have the trial --

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: There is de novo language in old statutes and old cases that indicate that what de novo means is to begin from scratch and do it all again, as if nothing had ever happened.
The more recent federal authorities seem to be working on some standard for de novo which give more play to the possibility of eliminating some issues than those old cases did.
We could have argued that the judge was required to redo it.

It seemed that in view of the purposes of the legislation and the statements in the congressional history that the proper approach was the approach taken by some of these recent federal decisions which indicate that de novo requires reconsideration of live evidence only to the extent that issues like credibility, motivation, veracity and those kinds of issues were present.

Apart from that, the district judge has a great deal of discretion to try to work out stipulations, to admit the prior record, and engage in a number of duplication-saving devices as long as he puts himself in a position to make a truly independent decision on the credibility questions.

I would like to speak for a minute, because I think that the government's position comes down largely to the question of the costs of rehearing and the costs in terms of economic and administrative considerations of, number one, not sending the motions to suppress to magistrates and, number two, requiring the judge to hear selected evidence rather than reading the transcript.

We have included in our brief some recent statistics that indicate that the whole issue of suppression motions, the hearing of suppression motions are not in any event a very substantial part of the workload of district judges or magistrates.
But beyond that, it seems to me that the best answer to that argument is the docket sheet in this case.
The government says that the interests of judicial efficiency has been saved by this procedure.
Well, all there was was a reading of the record.
But I would like to suggest that this motion to suppress would in all likelihood have been heard by a district judge in a day and ruled on from the bench.

What in fact happened was that it took five months, and the reason it took five months was because first the magistrate had to hold a hearing and then a transcript had to be prepared, which is not that common in most motions to suppress that I have been involved in if there is not going to be an appeal.

The parties, the lawyers, both of whom were government lawyers, had to prepare proposed factfindings and recommendations, the magistrate had to review all of this material and write a report to the district judge with proposed fact-findings, the parties had to file objections to the magistrate's report, the district judge had to read all of this record which by this time included a voluminous transcript, presumably in many cases he would hear oral argument and then he had to go about the process of trying to decide from the transcript with all this conflicting testimony what in fact happened.
Now, if any time were to be saved by having the district judge rehear selected testimony rather than reading this transcript.
I would submit that it would be a very minimal savings at best.

And we have included in our brief some references to some recent congressional hearings in which district judges have begged Congress not to give them appellate-type duties with respect to magistrate civil trial jurisdiction because they find that it is quicker for them to hear the issues again rather than reading through a transcript.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But the judge didn't have to send this to a magistrate.
If he wanted to save time, he could have tried it, couldn't he?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Couldn't he?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: -- if he thought it would save time, he could have, yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, couldn't he?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, what is your argument?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: As to why he sent it to the magistrate?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I mean he could have taken it himself and saved, what, five months?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I don't know.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, you said this case -- in this case, if the judge had tried the motion to suppress without the magistrate, he would have saved a whole lot of time, you say.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I think in reality that is true.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So what?
He didn't, and it was up to him.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: That's right, but I think that the government --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That wasn't an error, was it, to send it to the magistrate?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: No, he had the power to send it to the magistrate, there is no question about it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And he could have decided not to send it.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: I think when it comes down to the question of whether rehearing selected testimony is going to frustrate the purposes of this legislation, it has got to be considered in reference to the alternative and what the alternative is, the government's position is that the alternative is reading a transcript.
The Ninth Circuit's alternative is that a tape recording has to be prepared.

As I understand it, the Sixth Circuit still holds to its old Wedding v. Wingo rules which still represent the condition they were in at the time of Wingo v. Wedding, that a tape recording has to be prepared.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you mean the Ninth Circuit requires the district judge to listen to the tape record or that one be prepared?

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: The most recent discussion of that was in the Orand case which the government has cited in its brief, and the -- I think it was a habeas corpus situation, and the Ninth Circuit reversed the District Court stating that in that case he hadn't even had a transcript.

The Ninth Circuit noted that he also hadn't had a tape recording which was still the prevailing law of the circuit, and that it was remanded for him to reconsider whether he ought to have a tape recording.
They cited Campbell, they cited this case, so I don't think the requirements are really fixed yet.
But it is obvious under the statute that something has to be written in so that the judge has some basis for making his decision.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Ms. Gottschall, I might add that after looking at the cases I am just not sure what the rule is in the Seventh Circuit on resubmission of voluntariness to the jury, so I may have over-spoken.

turn.speaker: joan_b_gottschall
turn.label: Ms. Joan B. Gottschall
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you have something further, Mr. Levander?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.
First, 18 U.S.C. 3501 requires in a federal case if the defendant wants it that the jury consider voluntariness separate and apart from the pretrial submission.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Even after the judge --

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That is absolutely correct, Mr. Justice White.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: When was that statute passed?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That was passed in 1968 as part of the Omnibus Crime Control Act.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: After Jackson v. Denno?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So it codified the Massachusetts procedure in --

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So I didn't over-speak myself.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: The de novo language in this case, in this statute is much different than the de novo language that Mr. Justice Rehnquist was thinking about and which -- and the cases the respondent relies on.

This is not a de novo hearing, it is a de novo determination, and in the act itself Congress uses the words "hear" and "determine" and when it wants the District Court to do, and it enabled the magistrate to do so.
So therefore in contrasting that language, it seems quite clear that even in the language of the act, much less the legislative history, does support the government's position.

Second, respondent's position as to the due process point would render suspect numerous kinds of proceedings in which the original initial trier of fact, the person who evaluates credibility is not the person who makes a determination of fact.
That is, in agency proceedings --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Levander, none of those cases are cases in which the court is directed to make a de novo determination.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Well, in --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I understand Judge Sprecher's argument to be that when a de novo determination must be made and credibility is an issue, that then due process requires that the witnesses be heard.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Well, in Mildner v. Gulotta, the case involved bar proceeding, disbarment proceedings in the State of New York, precisely like the sort of situation.
It was a referee who conducted the official kind of proceeding, evaluated the witness's credibility, the lawyer's testimony against complaining witnesses, and his decision was not determinative.
He had no power to determine.
Thereafter the appellate division court in reviewing the record made the de novo determination, and the language is in the case.
The three-judge court upheld that statute, this Court summarily affirmed, and it seems to me that case is fairly dispositive of the due process point that is argued here by respondent.
And in that case there was some suggestion that the appellate courts were reversing the referee's findings.
Here, of course, the District Court has affirmed and adopted the magistrate's finding, the person who has evaluated the credibility.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, on that point of affirming versus reversing, do I correctly understand you to suggest that in making the de novo determination the judge may give some deference to the views of the magistrate?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: He is to credit it for what it is worth.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, that means he may give some deference to it, so it is not really a hundred percent de novo, it is like 99.5 percent.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: No, he first makes a de novo determination, a thorough review and he has to make the thorough review --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, his thorough review is that the evidence is in conflict, it depends on whether I believe (a) or (b), I really don't know without seeing them, so the only thing I can go on is that the magistrate believed (a).
Can he affirm on that basis?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: He can.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So he can give some deference to the determination?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So it is not a hundred percent de novo.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: But preceding his determination to credit the magistrate --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: He could be 50-50.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: -- there must be a de novo determination and the -- I see my time is up, but if I could just finish this one answer.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I would like you to.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Where he is reversing, where there is a pure swearing contest and he is reversing, it may be an abuse of discretion under the statute for him to simply ignore the credibility findings of the magistrate.
Again, he gives it some value.
He must give it some value, and if it is purely a swearing contest, he has abused his discretion in either not affirming the magistrate's evaluation or in rehearing the testimony.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: In either event, the words de novo mean he must give some deference to the magistrate under your view, if I understand you.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Only he gives it whatever it is worth, and he need not give it any deference, but he can.
He can always choose to rehear the --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, if he can, the language of the statute is mandatory -- it says he shall make a de novo determination.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Which would mean to me that he has to do it.
And if you are saying that he may give deference to the magistrate, it is not a 100 percent de novo determination.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: He doesn't give deference to the magistrate insofar --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, he can affirm but he can't reverse, if the evidence is evenly balanced.
That is what you told me.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: That's right, but then he --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Then the only difference between the cases of affirming and reversing is that in one case he gives deference to the magistrate and in the other he doesn't.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: He gives it for what it is worth.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It is worth something, that is what it is worth.
But your position is that it is worth something.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: If he wishes to make it so, otherwise he would rehear the testimony if he doesn't think that the magistrate's determination, he doesn't trust it, he thinks the evidence is truly equipoise.
That is not the case in this case and again the District Court affirmed the magistrate's findings.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Isn't your position at odds with the dictionary meaning of de novo?

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Well, whatever the dictionary meaning is, it is quite clear here what Congress had in mind, that --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The common understanding of what that phrase means, I don't know what the dictionary says either.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Well, anew I think it means and --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Anew.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: Well, he gives it a fresh look, and that is what Congress had in mind.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: A clean slate.

turn.speaker: andrew_j_levander
turn.label: Mr. Andrew J. Levander
turn.text: He starts by reviewing everything and then he can give credit to what he thinks deserves credit, and the legislative history and the decision in Campbell on which de novo is taken from show quite clearly what Congress had in mind, and it is a thorough review which he doesn't have to give deference as compared to subsection (a) where he has to give clearly erroneous deference to the magistrate's findings.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, counsel.
The case is submitted.
